Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the EPA Risk Management Program. This prevention program covers the CHA component of the manufacturing process in which CHA is present above the threshold quantity for the RMP rules.
The prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents. Some of the activities in the prevention program include:
Process safety information is provided to all employees upon hire and is accessible at all times.
Process hazard analyses are completed every five years by qualified personnel using techniques approved under the PSM standard.
Written operating procedures are used for training and guiding the work of operators and updated as needed.
Training is provided to all employees upon hire, and refresher training is given annually or upon request.
Operators, maintenance, and contractor personnel are qualified, trained in the general hazards in the facility, and informed of any temporary situations affecting safety.
Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted to insure that conditions for safe operation have been satisfied for starting new or modified equipment.
A program is in place to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process that includes written procedures, training requirements, work orders, and scheduled maintenance.
A hot work permit system assures that welding, cutting, and grinding work is done safely and properly.
A management of change system is in place to ensure that changes are managed safely.
Incidents are investigated and actions are taken as part of a continuous improvement effort.
Routine audits are conducted to assure safety

of equipment and practices.
The approach to process safety at Day-Glo Color involves employees and strives for continuing improvements in overall safety. The training, qualifications, and safety awareness of our operations, maintenance, and management personnel are key elements in reducing and mitigating accidents.

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no accidents/releases of cyclohexylamine at the facility that led to on-site deaths, injuries, or significant damage in the past five years. There are also no reported incidents of off-site consequences from an accidental release of cyclohexylamine.

Emergency Response Plan
Day-Glo Color has an evacuation procedure to ensure that in the event of an emergency the personnel on-site know how to evacuate the area where the emergency is occurring. The procedure identifies assembly locations and a list of individual to be contacted in order to mitigate the effects of a release. Because Day-Glo employees will not respond to cyclohexylamine emergencies, response activities have been coordinated with the Summit County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the local Fire Department.
